citation.article-title: Fervidobacterium nodosum gen. nov. and spec. nov., a new chemoorganotrophic, caldoactive, anaerobic bacterium.

p.s: Fervidobacterium (Fer. vi. do. bac. ter. i. um. L. adj. Fervidus hot; L. masc. n. bakterion a small rod; L. neut. n. Fervidobacterium, rod which grows at higher temperatures)
Rods occur singly, in pairs and in chains, are 0.5-0.55 μm by 1.0-2.5 μm, stain Gram-negative, do not sporulate and are motile.
A majority of the cells produce terminal swellings, called spheroids.
Spheroids are 1.0- 2.0 μm in diameter and only one spheroid is produced per cell.
Rotund bodies formed due to multiple divisions of the cell within the spheroid are also frequently observed.
TYEG agar deep (2%; 65°C colonies are 1 mm in diameter, uniformly round and creamish white after 48 h incubation.
Growth occurs between 41°C and 79°C and from pH 6 to 8.0 with temperature optimum of 70°C and pH optimum of 7.0.
Utilises various hexoses; inhibited by tetracycline, penicillin and chloramphenicol but resistant to D-cycloserine.
Fermentation end products from glucose are lactate, CO2, H2, acetate with minor production of ethanol.
G + C Guanine plus cytosine content of the DNA. 33.7 mol % as determined by the thermal denaturation method.
Slightly acidic, neutral and alkaline hot springs of Rotorua and Waimangu thermal areas of New Zealand.
